This theory was first proposed by the English philosopher and scientist Francis Bacon in the 17th century.
According to Bacon, the human eye does not contain any small probes or sensors that detect light directly. Instead, the eye acts like a "dark chamber" that receives light from the outside world and reflects it back to the brain. The light that enters the eye is not perceived as a series of tiny prods or sensations, but rather as a continuous flow of light that is emitted by objects outside of the body.
Bacon's emission theory of vision was influential in the development of modern optics and the understanding of how the human eye works. It challenged the prevailing view at the time, which held that light was transmitted to the eye through a series of tiny tubes or channels. Bacon's theory helped to establish the idea that light is an external phenomenon that interacts with the eye and brain in a more direct way.
While the emission theory of vision has been largely superseded by modern scientific discoveries, it remains an important milestone in the history of optics and the understanding of human vision. Today, we know that the eye does contain specialized light-sensitive cells called photoreceptors (rods and cones) that convert light into electrical signals that are transmitted to the brain. However, Bacon's idea that light is perceived by sensing the light emitted by objects outside of the body remains an important aspect of the theory of vision.

He was the first to advocate for a standardized measuring system, which he believed was essential for accurate scientific measurements and trade.
Archimedes believed that the lack of a standardized measuring system was causing confusion and errors in trade and commerce. He argued that a uniform measuring system would ensure that goods were accurately measured and traded, and that it would help to prevent fraud and deception.
Archimedes' advocacy for a standardized measuring system was based on his understanding of the principles of geometry and the importance of accurate measurements in scientific inquiry. He believed that a standardized measuring system would allow for more accurate calculations and measurements, which would in turn lead to a deeper understanding of the natural world.
One of Archimedes' most famous contributions to the field of measuring systems is his development of the "Archimedes' principle," which states that the upward buoyant force on an object is equal to the weight of the fluid it displaces. This principle forms the basis of modern fluid mechanics and has had a profound impact on the field of engineering.
In addition to his work on the Archimedes' principle, Archimedes also developed a number of other measuring devices, including the "Archimedes' screw," which was used to lift water from a lower level to a higher level, and the "Archimedes' balance," which was used to measure the weight of objects with great accuracy.
Overall, Archimedes' advocacy for a standardized measuring system was a groundbreaking idea that laid the foundation for modern measurement systems. His work in this field has had a lasting impact on science, engineering, and trade, and his legacy continues to inspire scientists and engineers to this day.
